buddhist.description: Dharma wheel (8-spoked) representing the Noble Eightfold Path

celtic.description: Shamrock (three-leaf clover) sacred to Celtic tradition

chinese.description: Dragon representing imperial power and cosmic forces

christian.description: Christian cross representing crucifixion and salvation

egyptian.font: Segoe UI Historic, Noto Sans Egyptian Hieroglyphs, serif
egyptian.note: Uses Egyptian hieroglyphs requiring special font support
egyptian.description: Ankh symbol (â˜¥) representing eternal life - SVG replaces hieroglyph ğ“‚€

freemasons.description: Square and compass with G representing Freemasonry

greek.description: Thunderbolt of Zeus representing divine power

hindu.description: Om (à¥) symbol representing the sacred primordial sound

islamic.description: Star and crescent representing Islamic faith

japanese.description: Torii gate marking sacred Shinto spaces

jewish.note: Star of David; Menorah as alternate
jewish.description: Star of David (Magen David) representing Jewish identity

mayan.note: Maize/corn, sacred crop central to Mayan creation mythology
mayan.description: Maize representing creation and sustenance in Mayan cosmology

native_american.note: Eagle (sacred to many tribes); feather as alternate
native_american.description: Eagle representing spirit messenger and vision

norse.note: Sword and Yggdrasil (World Tree) shown together in hero section (line 254)
norse.description: Viking sword with Yggdrasil (World Tree) representing warrior culture and cosmology

persian.description: Sacred fire representing Ahura Mazda's divine light

roman.note: Roman eagle (SPQR standard); same as Native American icon but different cultural context
roman.description: Roman eagle (aquila) representing imperial power and legions

sumerian.description: Dingir star symbol representing divinity - SVG replaces cuneiform ğ’€­

tarot.note: Playing card/Joker representing the Fool's journey
tarot.description: Tarot card representing the Fool's journey and divination

_metadata.note: Icons extracted from mythos/*/index.html files in the HTML header <h1> tags and .hero-icon-display divs. SVG versions created to replace emoji/Unicode for better rendering and theming support.
patternLocations: Header h1 tag (line ~215-240 in most files)
Hero section .hero-icon-display div (line ~229-254 in most files)

specialCases.egyptian: SVG ankh replaces hieroglyph ğ“‚€ which requires special font support
specialCases.sumerian: SVG star/dingir replaces cuneiform ğ’€­ which requires special font support
specialCases.norse: SVG combines sword and Yggdrasil tree in single icon
specialCases.islamic: Header only, no hero section icon display in older template
specialCases.jewish: Header only, no hero section icon display in older template
specialCases.persian: Header only, no hero section icon display in older template

iconDuplicates.note: Roman eagle and Native American eagle share same emoji but SVG versions have distinct styles representing different cultural symbols
